Award.AwardTitle: Merging Crop Modeling and Genetics: A Training Workshop, August 2014, Univerity of Florida.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant genomics projects have generated a cornucopia of data ranging from an ever increasing number of genome sequences to a vast array of gene expression data. However, one of the major challenges facing the plant biology community at this time is establishing reliable connections between a genotype and its corresponding range of potential phenotypes that can be generated under a range of environments. Gene-based crop simulation models (CSMs) are valuable tools to study gene function in the context of a crop phenotype in diverse environments, and also as a plant breeding tool. NSF funds will support a training workshop to make the research community aware of the potential benefits of incorporating genetic information into crop models. The workshop will promote interactions between crop modelers, breeders and geneticists, and will provide training of advanced graduate students and postdoctoral associates in quantitative genetics, crop modeling, phenotyping and bioinformatics.

Gene-based crop simulation models (CSMs) are dynamic tools that use mathematical expressions to represent plant growth and development under different environments; for this reason, they provide a unique opportunity to establish a bridge between the genotype domain and the more plastic phenotype domain. Calibration of CSMs yields a set of genotype specific parameters (GSPs), while genetic analysis can identify the genes associated with GSPs, and help turn the GSPs into mathematical functions of the controlling genes. This approach is being pursued by geneticist, breeders and crop-modelers at the University of Florida in collaboration with colleagues at North Dakota State University, the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Puerto Rico, and the International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT) (Colombia). The 6-day workshop will include lectures and hands-on exercises in dry- and wet-lab settings. A manual covering the different topics that will be addressed in the workshop will be made available to participants and also to the research community along with a video of the workshop through a dedicated website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dynamic crop simulation models use mathematical expressions to represent plant growth and development, and these expressions are set up to respond in a predictable manner to variations in environmental conditions during the crop growing season. However, before a crop model can be used to predict the behavior of particular variety of the crop, the model has to be calibrated under a range of environmental conditions. The calibration process yields a set of parameters that are specific to that particular crop variety. This process has to be performed for each crop variety that will be simulated indicating that the parameters contain information associated with the genetic makeup of each variety. Once the parameter values are estimated for a variety, a computer could be used to study the performance of that variety under different real or hypothetical environments. Variety development and variety trials at different locations and times of the year is what plant breeders have to perform to assess the adaptability of new varieties resulting from their breeding programs. Overall, this is a long and expensive process. Thus, crop models could potentially save considerable time and effort. However, working with one genotype will continue to prolong the process. Genetic analysis can identify the genes that control growth and development, and proper statistical analysis can be used to estimate the effect of identified gene variants on growth and development. This genetic information can then be encoded in crop models to enable them to predict crop responses to different environments and managerial protocols with only two inputs: the genetic makeup of the crop and the environmental conditions. In fact, gene-based crop simulation models could be turned into expert systems that can identify the best combination of genes a breeder needs to assemble into a new variety that will be best suited for a given environment, known or projected.

 

The main objective of the “Merging Crop Modeling and Genetics” workshop was to foster interactions between crop modelers and plant breeders/geneticists by bringing them together and presenting theory and results generated by the University of Florida team. In addition to presenting results obtained under NSF award IOS-0923975, workshop participants had a chance to process and analyze part of the data generated in the research project. Along with the lectures and exercises, several discussion sessions were held during the workshop. Although there was a general agreement about the utility and benefit of merging modeling and genetics, some of the discussions addressed current barriers for collaboration between modelers and breeders. Traditionally, crop modelers require data collection in excess of what most breeding programs can afford; this is an obvious barrier that is difficult to overcome. However, the results presented in the workshop indicated that current models will need to be modified by breaking them down into modules that address simple physiological processes. The modular structure facilitates the incorporation of genetic information into components that contribute to growth and development processes without having to do this for all processes, including effects caused by interactions between specific genes and particular environmental factors. The output of these modules can be integrated into a central model. The advantages of the modular structure are that in addition to increasing the accuracy of the model through the incorporation of genetic information, it can also facilitate the collaboration of modelers and breeders focusing on just a few key phenotypic traits at a time. This is possible because the current models could be modified progressively through the replacement of some internal routines with process specific modules.

 

The broader impacts of the workshop are expected to occ...
